thread.title: UK GAS-Prompt prices ease on oversupplied system
thread.title_full: UK GAS-Prompt prices ease on oversupplied system

title: UK GAS-Prompt prices ease on oversupplied system
text:
* Gas system oversupplied by 12 mcm 
* Gas for immediate delivery at 38.55 p/therm 
Oct (HKSE: 3366-OL.HK - news ) 2 (Reuters) - British prompt gas prices eased on Friday as lower exports to Belgium compounded a supply glut. 
Gas for instant delivery was trading at 38.55 pence per therm at 0850 GMT, down 0.20 pence from the previous session, while prices for the weekend were down by 0.30 pence at 38.50 pence/therm. 
Gas for delivery on Monday was steady at 39 pence per therm. 
With daily demand pegged at 211 million cubic metres (mcm) per day, Britain's gas market was oversupplied by 12 mcm, according to National Grid (LSE: NG.L - news ) . 
Maximum temperatures in Britain are forecast to fall to 17 degrees Celsius on Saturday from 19 degrees on Friday, but are expected to rise next week, according to the country's Met Office. 
The system oversupply was partly due to lower exports to Belgium via the Interconnector pipeline compared with the previous day, analysts at Thomson Reuters Point Carbon said. 
A planned outage at Britain's North Morecambe gas sub-terminal, due to end on Friday, has been extended indefinitely. Oliver Sanderson, an analyst at Thomson Reuters (Dusseldorf: TOC.DU - news ) Point Carbon, said this was possibly a reaction to low prices. 
In the power market, Torness-2 nuclear reactor is expected to restart on Friday, reducing the need for gas-fired power generation. 
Further along the curve, front-month November gas prices were down 0.05 pence at 41.25 pence/therm. 
The new forward seasonal contract, summer 2016, was down 0.15 pence at 38.50 pence/therm. 
In the Netherlands, the day-ahead gas price at the TTF hub was down 0.17 euros at 17.83 euros per megawatt-hour. 
In Europe's carbon market, the benchmark EU Allowance (EUA) edged down by 0.04 euros to 8.13 euros a tonne. (Reporting by Nerijus Adomaitis in Oslo; Editing by Pravin Char)
